questions.text: A 55-year-old male presented with angina. Coronary angiography revealed a block in the right coronary artery. The condition is likely to cause a ​decrease in blood supply through all of the following blood vessels except:
questions.solution:
Circumflex artery is not a branch of the right coronary artery. It is a branch of the left coronary artery.

The branches of the right coronary artery are:

  • Right conal artery - It is the first branch of the right coronary artery.
  • Artery of the SA node 
  • Acute right marginal artery 
  • Posterior interventricular artery (in 65% population)
  • Atrial and anterior and posterior ventricular branches

questions.text: A patient with parathyroid deficiency 10 days after inadvertent damage to the parathyroid glands during thyroid surgery would probably have

choices.text: Low plasma phosphate and Ca2+ levels and tetanus.
Low plasma Ca2+ level, increased muscular excitability, and upper extremity muscle spasms.
High plasma phosphate and Ca2+ levels and bone demineralization.
Increased muscular excitability, a high plasma Ca2+ level, and bone demineralization

questions.solution:
Parathyroid hormone deficiency leads to low Ca+2 levels and tetany. (Not tetanus, caused by an infection of bacteria Clostridium tetani)

Actions of PTH include

  • PTH stimulates bone resorption, causing the release of calcium into the extracel­lular fluid;
  • PTH increases reabsorption of calcium and decreases phosphate reabsorption by the renal tubules, leading to decreased excretion of calcium and increased excretion of phosphate; and
  • PTH is necessary for the conversion of 25­-hydroxycholecalciferol to 1,25­ dihydroxycholecalciferol, which, in turn, increases calcium absorption by the intestines. 

So, a deficiency of PTH would lead to low Ca+2 levels and high phosphate levels. 

The signs of tetany in humans include Chvostek sign, a quick contraction of the ipsilateral facial muscles elicited by tapping over the facial nerve at the angle of the jaw, and Trousseau sign, a spasm of the muscles of the upper extremity that causes flexion of the wrist and thumb.

A hand being held similarly to Trousseau's sign (above).

questions.text: A 6-month-old boy was admitted with failure to thrive. Laboratory tests showed hypoglycemia and high glutamine and uracil levels in urine. Gastric tube feeding was not tolerated. The child became comatose and then parenteral dextrose was given. The child recovered from coma within 24 hours. What is the likely enzyme defect?
questions.solution:
From the given clinical scenario, the diagnosis is hyperammonemia type 2, which is due to the deficiency of the enzyme ornithine transcarbamoylase.

There is an accumulation of carbamoyl phosphate, which then enters into pyrimidine synthesis producing orotic acid and uracil and leading to orotic aciduria and high uracil in blood and urine.

High glutamine: Since the ammonia from glutamine is not converted into urea, its level increases. Glutamate is not regenerated.

Hypoglycemia: Since glutamate is not available for transamination, amino acids cannot be used for gluconeogenesis. Hence, the glucose level drops in blood.

Treatment:

Limiting intake of ammonia and increasing its excretion. Dietary protein, a metabolic source of ammonium, is restricted and caloric intake is provided by glucose and fat.

Addition of Phenylbutyrate which scavenges nitrogen.

Related Pearl: Urea Cycle and its disorders

questions.text: A 20-year-old woman presenting with fatigue and weakness shows the following laboratory values: Hemoglobin 9 gm%; MCV  70 fl; MCH 22 pg/cell; and RDW 28. There is no history of blood transfusion. The peripheral smear is as seen below. What is the most likely diagnosis of the patient?
questions.solution:
The above peripheral smear showing microcytic, hypochromic blood picture with pencil cells implies that the most likely diagnosis for the patient is iron-deficiency anemia. 

Hemogram:

  • MCV of 70 fl is suggestive of microcytosis (normal MCV is 82–96 fl)
  • MCH of 22 pg is suggestive of hypochromia (normal MCH is 27–33 pg/cell)
  • Red cell distribution width (RDW) of 28 is suggestive of anisocytosis (normal RDW is 11.5-14.5%).

questions.text: A 22-year-old male presented with high-grade fever, and purpuric rash as shown in the image below. CSF sample showed gram-negative diplococci. Which of the following is the most likely aetiology?
questions.solution:
The above image shows a purpuric rash seen in meningococcemia caused by Neisseria meningitidis, which are gram-negative diplococci. 

Pathogenesis & clinical features:

  • The organism enters the body through the nasopharynx. From nasopharynx, they enter the bloodstream producing bacteremia, and the symptoms may resemble upper respiratory tract infection.
  • Fulminant meningococcemia is the severe form, where the patient presents with high-grade fever and hemorrhagic rash. There is thrombosis of several small blood vessels in various organs with perivascular infiltration and petechial haemorrhages. 
  • Some patients with fulminant meningococcemia may also develop disseminated intravascular coagulation, and circulatory collapse, a condition known as Waterhouse–Friderichsen syndrome.

questions.text: A child who is a victim under POCSO act is brought to the department forensic medicine for age estimation. The X-ray image of the hand is shown below. What is the likely age of the child?
questions.solution:
The child's age is likely to be 13 years.

In the above X-ray image of the wrist and hand, all the carpal bones are seen. The lower epiphysis of the first metacarpal has not united with the shaft. This suggests that the age of the child is 12 to 15 years.

questions.text: You are counseling a patient with gastroesophageal reflux disease about the need for long-term therapy with proton-pump inhibitors. All of the following are complications of this therapy, except:
questions.solution:
Long-term PPI therapy is not associated with hypogastrinemia but is associated with hypergastrinemia. This hypergastrinemia contributes to rebound gastric acid hypersecretion if PPI therapy is discontinued.

Chronic PPI therapy is associated with: 

  • Decreased vitamin B12 absorption
  • Increased susceptibility to infections- hospital-acquired pneumonia, pseudomembranous enterocolitis
  • Reduced calcium absorption increases the risk of fractures

questions.text: 65 year old male presents with painless cervical lymphadenopathy and right sided deafness. On examination, dull tympanic membrane on right side and tympanometry shows curve B. Most probable diagnosis is
questions.solution:
• Painless cervical lymphadenopathy is the most common presenting feature of nasopharyngeal carcinoma.
  • Presence of unilateral serous otitis media in an adult should raise suspicion of nasopharyngeal growth. (Eustachian tube obstruction leads to serous otitis media which causes deafness)

  • Painless cervical lymphadenopathy is the most common (60-90%) presenting feature of nasopharyngeal carcinoma followed by- 

    • Hearing loss
    • Nasal obstruction
    • Epistaxis
    • Cranial nerve palsies -Cranial nerves V and VI are the most commonly involved among all the cranial nerves. 
    • Headache
    • Earache
    • Neck pain
    • Weight loss
  • Dull tympanic membrane and type B curve on tympanometry are features of serous otitis media.

questions.text: A 55-year-old woman is being counseled for surgery for her long-standing dacryocystitis. Which of the following is the surgery of choice?
questions.solution:
The treatment of choice for chronic dacryocystitis is dacryocystorhinostomy (DCR) as it re-establishes the lacrimal drainage.

One of the sequelae of chronic dacryocystitis is mucocele formation, which when infected, leads to pyocele formation and finally lacrimal fibrosis. Treatment of lacrimal sac fibrosis is dacryocystectomy.

questions.text: A 15 years old girl has received complete immunization against tetanus 7 years ago. Now she presents with a contaminated wound sustained 6 hours ago. She should now be given?

choices.text: Human tetanus immunoglobulin and single dose of toxoid

questions.solution:
The girl should be given a single dose of tetanus toxoid alone

She presented with a contaminated wound sustained 6 hours ago and she has received complete immunization against tetanus 7 years back, which comes under Category B of Tetanus Immunization.

According to the recommendations of the CDC:

Td - Tetanus and Diptheria

Tdap for children and Td for adults but Tdap is preferred to Td for adults who have never received Tdap.

 

Categories of Tetanus immunization:

  • Category A - Taken a complete course of TT/booster within past 5 years
  • Category B - Taken a complete course of TT/booster within the past > 5 years < 10 years.

Note:

WHO recommends a 3-dose primary vaccination series with tetanus-diphtheria containing vaccine followed by 3 booster doses. Ideally, there should be at least 4 years between booster doses.

questions.text: A study was conducted on a group of 500 patients having carcinoma lung and another group of 300 was chosen from the general population. Both these groups were questioned on their exposure to smoking. What kind of study is this?
questions.solution:
This is a case–control study. In this scenario, 500 patients constitute the cases and 300 people constitute the controls, and the study is done from effect to cause as the disease has already occurred.

Related Pearl: Case Control Study

  • In a case control study, progression is from effect to cause as outcome or disease has already occurred.
  • It is also called retrospective study.
  • Design of Case Control Study

 

    • Steps of Case Control Study
      • Selection of cases and controls
      • Matching
      • Measurement of exposure
      • Analysis in the form of exposure rates, risk ratio, and odds ratio
    • Advantages and Disadvantages

Rapid and inexpensive

questions.text: If  the sensitivity and specificity  of a screening test are 90% and 95% respectively, calculate the positive likelihood ratio:
questions.solution:
The positive likelihood ratio of this screening test is 18.

A positive likelihood ratio, or LR+, is the probability that a positive test would be expected in a patient with a disease divided by the probability that a positive test would be expected in a patient without a disease. In other words, an LR+ is the true positivity rate divided by the false positivity rate.

Positive Likelihood Ratio= Sensitivity/(1-Specificity) 

LR+= 0.9/1-0.95= 0.9/0.05 = 18.

Similarly , Negative Likelihood Ratio= (1- Sensitivity)/Specificity

Related Pearl: Validity of a Screening Test

  • Validity/ Accuracy of a screening test depends upon the sensitivity, specificity, and predictive accuracy of the test.
  • It represents the closeness to a true value/ actual value.
  • These are the inherent properties of a screening test.
  • PPV and NPV are dependent on the Prevalence of disease.
  • Sensitivity & Speciifity are independent of prevalence of disease.

questions.text: Mr. Ramesh presented with a 3-week history of crampy abdominal pain associated with diarrhoea. Which of the following features supports a diagnosis of irritable bowel syndrome?

choices.text: Persistent diarrhoea after a 48 hour fast
Onset of symptoms during a period of stress

questions.solution:
The onset of symptoms during a period of stress or emotional upset is a feature that supports a diagnosis of irritable bowel syndrome (IBS).

Features in favour of IBS:

  • Abdominal pain that improves/worsens with defecation
  • Association with stress or emotional symptoms
  • Small volume of stools

Features not in favour of IBS:

  • Onset of symptoms in old age
  • Presence of fever and weight loss
  • Persistent diarrhoea after a 48h fast
  • Nocturnal diarrhoea
  • Steatorrhoea

questions.text: A 27-year-old woman presents with urinary frequency, urgency, and burning during urination of two days duration. She has also noticed a scant vaginal discharge. Which of the following additional findings would be most suggestive of pyelonephritis in this patient?
questions.solution:
In the given case scenario, WBC casts are most suggestive of pyelonephritis. 

The urine contains many leukocytes (pyuria) derived from the inflammatory infiltrate, but pyuria does not differentiate upper from lower urinary tract infection. The finding of leukocyte casts, typically rich in neutrophils (pus casts), indicates renal involvement because casts are formed only in tubules.

Note:Ascending infection is the most common cause of clinical pyelonephritis.

Note: Sterile pyuria is defined as white cells in the urine in the absence of significant bacterial growth.

questions.text: A postgraduate student is assisting in the emergency trauma surgery of an HIV-infected person noted to have severe oropharyngeal candidiasis. He suffers a bleeding puncture wound on his right index finger, through the glove. Which of the following is correct regarding post-exposure prophylaxis for HIV in this situation?
questions.solution:
Recommended Post-exposure prophylaxis(PEP) is a three drug regimen which includes Lamivudine 300mg , Tenofovir 300mg and Dolutegravir 50mg. A regimen for post-exposure prophylaxis for HIV with two ARV drugs is effective, but three drugs are preferred. The PEP must be initiated ideally within 2 hours and certainly within 72 hours. WHO recommended PEP regimen:

Drug combination Recommendation for PEP Duration
Tenofovir (TDF) 300mg + Lamivudine(3TC) 300mg + Dolutegravir (DTG) 50mg    Once daily 4 weeks

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman presented with persistent headaches over the last 1 month. Her father and paternal uncle suffered from kidney disease and both died in their 50's of a 'brain bleed'. Her blood pressure is 160/110 mm Hg and had also been elevated during a previous visit. Which of the following investigations should be avoided in this patient?

choices.text: Contrast enhanced CT of the abdomen
Non-contrast CT scan of the abdomen
MR angiography of the cerebral vasculature

questions.solution:
This clinical scenario is suggestive of autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease (ADPKD). These patients usually have impaired renal function. Hence, contrast-enhanced CT (CECT) would usually be avoided due to the risk of contrast nephrotoxicity.

The following investigations are done in patients with ADPKD:

  • USG abdomen - for screening and diagnosis
  • Non-contrast CT abdomen - more sensitive and picks up cysts of smaller size
  • MR-angiography of brain - pre-symptomatic screening for intracerebral aneurysms

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents to the clinic with a history of greenish discharge from the nipple for the past 1 month. Personal history is significant for cigarette smoking. On compression of her breast, greenish discharge from multiple ducts was observed. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis of a patient with greenish discharge from multiple ducts is duct ectasia. 

Duct ectasia is the dilatation of breast ducts. It is the most common cause of nipple discharge in nonlactating women. This condition is associated with smoking and diabetes.

The initial stage of this disease consists of dilatation of one or more lactiferous ducts. These ducts get filled with stagnant brown or green colored secretions. In the later stages, the accumulation of fluid in the lactiferous ducts leads to infection and inflammation, causing periductal mastitis. The infections are most often mixed infections of aerobic and anaerobic flora of the skin.

Patients may present with nipple discharge, abscess, fistula or nipple retraction.

Related Pearl: Discharges from the nipple

Discharges from the nipple:

Discharge from the surface

  • Skin diseases (eczema, psoriasis)
  • Rare causes (e.g., chancre)

    • Intraductal papilloma
    • Intraductal carcinoma
    • Duct ectasia
  • Serous (any colour)
    • Fibrocystic disease

Discharge from more than one duct

  • The most common cause of blood-stained discharge from multiple ducts is duct carcinoma.
  • The most common cause of serous discharge from the breast is fibrocystic disease of breast.

questions.text: A 9-year-old girl is brought to the casualty with a history of abdominal pain and vomiting for the past 4 hours. On examination, the patient is febrile. Rebound tenderness in the right iliac fossa is seen. Which among the following is the preferred imaging modality in this patient?

choices.text: Erect X Ray of the abdomen

questions.solution:
The clinical scenario is suggestive of acute appendicitis. In the pediatric population, ultrasound of the abdomen is the preferred imaging modality to identify the presence of an inflamed appendix. It avoids the risk of radiation exposure. 

In adults, the best imaging modality is a CT scan.

questions.text: A 30 years old male presents with continuous discomfort in the right hypochondrium and on examination shows presence of enlarged liver 8cm below the costal margins. The image below shows CT radiograph. The probable diagnosis is
questions.solution:
The above image shows CT scan of the liver with hydatid cyst seen as a hypodense lesion with internal septation.

Hydatid cysts result from infection by the Echinococcus, and can result in cyst formation anywhere in the body.

Causative agent:

There are two main strains which include:

  1. Echinococcus granulosus: more common
    • pastoral: dog is a main host; most common form
    • sylvatic: wolf is a main host
  2. Echinococcus alveolaris/multilocularis: less common but more invasive; fox is a main host

Investigation:

  • CT examination reveals fluid density cyst, with frequent peripheral focal areas of calcification, usually indicates no active infection if completely circumferential.
  • Septation and daughter cysts may be visualised. The water-lily sign indicates a cyst with floating, undulating membrane, caused by a detached endocyst.
  • May also show hyperdense internal septa representing a spoke wheel pattern within a cyst.

questions.text: Identify the imaging modality.
questions.solution:
The image depicts a retrograde pyelogram.

Retrograde Pyelogram is particularly valuable when IVP/CT is contraindicated and excels at providing detailed imaging of the collecting system, especially for evaluating ureteral strictures and filling defects, making it especially useful in surgical planning. 

Other Options:

Option B: In Retrograde urethrogram, the urethra is visualized with the instillation of contrast into the anterior urethra (penile urethra and bulbar urethra). It helps diagnose anterior urethral abnormalities. The following image shows an image of retrograde urethrogram contrast leakage at the membranous urethra.

Option C: Intravenous Pyelography (IVP) provides comprehensive visualization of the entire urinary collecting system, useful for detecting stones, tumors, and anatomical abnormalities, though it's becoming less common with the advent of CT urography and has limitations in patients with renal insufficiency or contrast allergies. 

Option D: Antegrade Pyelography, performed through a nephrostomy tube, is particularly useful when retrograde access isn't possible and helps evaluate obstruction below the kidney, often being employed in patients with existing nephrostomy tubes. The image shows an antegrade pyelogram of grade III hydronephrosis with obstruction at the ureterovesical junction.

questions.text: A 33-year-old female patient comes with complaints of menorrhagia for the past 3 months. The duration and regularity of her menstrual cycles are normal. Non-hormonal management has been tried without success. What is the most appropriate next step?
questions.solution:
Hormonal therapy is the next best step in the given scenario of menorrhagia that is unresponsive to non-hormonal therapy. 

Menorrhagia is defined as heavy but regular menstrual bleeding. It can be acute (<6 months) or chronic (>6 months).

It is managed as follows:

  • Medical - first line of treatment.  
    • NSAIDs
    • Tranexamic acid  
    • OCPs/progestogens - if non-hormonal management fails 
    • Mirena IUCD
    • Blood transfusion, if required 
  • Surgical - if medical management fails, depending on the diagnosis:
    • Endometrial ablation - hysteroscopic, TCRE, RITEA, microwave, NovaSure, etc
    • Uterine artery embolization
    • Uterine tamponade
    • Hysterectomy - if all minimally invasive methods fail

questions.text: A woman recently became pregnant following a history of repeated abortions. She was anxious and wanted to undergo karyotyping this time to detect chromosomal disorders pre-natally. Barr body was found to be absent in her report. Which of the following is associated with an absent Barr body?
questions.solution:
Barr body is absent in female having 45 X0 genome.

Barr body

  • Densely staining inactivated condensed X chromosome present in each somatic cell of a female is found in the nucleus.
  • Chromatid body (Barr body or sex chromatin) is derived from one of the two X chromosomes which become inactivated.
  • The number of Barr bodies is thus one less than the number of X chromosomes.

Turner's syndrome is female without Barr body.

Klinefelter's syndrome is male with Barr body.

Note:

  • Lyon hypothesis states that only one of the two X chromosomes in a female is functional, the other becomes inactive during embryogenesis.
  • Davidson bodies are small nuclear buds of chromatin shaped like a drumstick found in neutrophils of females.

questions.text: A 33-week-pregnant lady with pre-eclampsia presenting with features suggestive of HELLP syndrome should be best managed by _______

choices.text: Give steroids and wait till 37 weeks
Give MgSo4 and deliver at 36 weeks

questions.solution:
The definitive management of PIH/eclampsia is termination of pregnancy only.

Indications for termination of pregnancy, irrespective of gestational age, in cases of pre-eclampsia are as follows:

  • Severe pre-eclampsia
  • Eclampsia (give MgSO4 followed by induction of labor)
  • HELLP syndrome
  • Pulmonary edema
  • Significant renal dysfunction, coagulopathy
  • Fetal compromise

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy presents with a short history of facial oedema that has now progressed to total body swelling involving the face, abdomen, scrotum, and feet. Urinalysis revealed protein 4+ with no hematuria and a urine protein:creatinine ratio of 3. What is the initial treatment of choice for this child?
questions.solution:
The clinical picture and investigations are suggestive of minimal change nephrotic syndrome and the initial treatment of choice is corticosteroids such as prednisolone.

Minimal change nephrotic syndrome is the most common cause of nephrotic syndrome. It is seen in ages 2-6 years with a clinical picture of nephrotic syndrome with

  • heavy proteinuria
  • oedema
  • hypoalbuminemia
  • hyperlipidemia.

They show excellent response to steroid therapy. A daily dose of 2mg/kg (max 60mg) for 6 weeks followed by an alternate day dose of 1.5mg/kg (max 40mg) for the next 6-8 weeks is recommended.

questions.text: A construction worker got entrapped in a collapsed building. He sustained severe injury over his legs. Which of the following features is unlikely to be seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a worker sustaining severe injury over his leg following entrapment is suggestive of crush syndrome. In this condition, hypokalemia is not seen.

Crush syndrome can result when a limb is compressed for a prolonged period. For e.g. getting crushed or entrapped in a vehicle or rubble and after extended use of a pneumatic antishock garment. This results in hypoperfusion and myonecrosis in the crushed limb. When the limb is released from the compression, toxic metabolites get released to cause reperfusion injury. 

Crush syndrome can result in a systemic reaction due to tissue necrosis. Free myoglobin can lead to acute tubular necrosis and renal failure. Myonecrosis can lead to metabolic acidosis with hyperkalemia and hypocalcemia. The procoagulants escaped into the systemic circulation can produce systemic coagulopathy. 

Management of crush syndrome:

  • Encouraging high urine flow, along with alkalization of urine with sodium bicarbonate to prevent precipitation of myoglobin in the renal tubules
  • Renal hemofiltration if there is oliguria or renal failure
  • If compartment syndrome is confirmed, then fasciotomy is performed
  • Radical excision of necrosed muscle to avoid sepsis
  • Aggressive management of the open wound

Related Pearl: Acute compartment and Crush syndrome

1. Acute Compartment Syndrome

Acute compartment syndrome is an elevation of the intracompartmental pressure (ICP) which increases the risk for tissue ischemia and necrosis.

Causes: Fractures (70%) and severe soft tissue injuries (30%). Common fractures causing compartment syndrome include tibial diaphyseal (most common), distal radius, and forearm fractures. 

Pathology: Increased pressure in one of the osseofascial compartments due to bleeding, oedema or inflammation. A vicious cycle of ischemia → edema→ ischemia leading to necrosis of the muscles and nerves within the compartment in 6 hours or less. 

Clinical features: Five Ps: Pain, Paraesthesia, Pallor, Paralysis and Pulselessness. 

Management: Fasciotomy to decompress the threatened compartment if the differential pressure (ΔP) goes < 30 mmHg. 

 

2. Crush syndrome 

Crush syndrome is the systemic manifestation of muscle necrosis. It is commonly caused due to prolonged external compression of an extremity. 

Causes: Crush injuries sustained during motor vehicle accidents, earthquakes, mining and other occupational accidents.

Pathology: Underperfusion of muscle causes myonecrosis. When the limb is freed, there is a release of toxic metabolites causing reperfusion injury. Reactive oxygen metabolites create further tissue injury. Free myoglobin can get precipitated in the renal glomeruli. 

Clinical features: The affected limb is pulseless, red, swollen and blistered. Sensation and muscle power may be lost. There can be signs of impaired renal function, metabolic acidosis, hyperkalemia and hypocalcaemia.

Management: Encouraging high urine output, alkalization of the urine, hemofiltration, radical excision of dead muscles, fasciotomy if there is compartment syndrome.

questions.text: A 72-year-old woman is admitted with complaints of fever with dysuria for 5 days. Her husband reports that she now appears withdrawn and apathetic. She had complained of seeing bugs crawling on her hand. She is drowsy on examination. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of an acute decline in the level of awareness and visual hallucinations (seeing bugs crawling on hand) in an elderly female admitted with fever and dysuria suggests a diagnosis of delirium.

Delirium is characterized by:

  • Acute decline in the level of awareness 
  • Global impairment of cognitive functions (particularly attention)

It also involves:

  • Perceptual disturbances like illusions and hallucinations
  • Abnormal psychomotor activity
  • Sleep cycle impairment.

The Confusion Assessment Method (CAM) is a diagnostic algorithm for delirium. The diagnosis of delirium requires the presence of features 1 and 2 and either feature 3 or 4.

  • Feature 1: Acute onset and fluctuating course
    • Positive responses to the following questions satisfy this feature:
      Is there evidence of an acute change in mental status from the patient’s baseline? Does it fluctuate during the day, or does it increase and decrease in severity?
  • Feature 2: Inattention
    • Positive response to the following question satisfies this feature: Is there difficulty focusing attention, easily distractibility, or difficulty keeping track of what was being said?
  • Feature 3: Disorganized thinking
    • A positive response to the following question satisfies this feature: Was the patient’s thinking disorganized or incoherent. Was there rambling or irrelevant conversation, an unclear or illogical flow of ideas, or unpredictable switching from subject to subject?
  • Feature 4: Altered level of consciousness
    • This feature is satisfied by any answer other than “alert” to the following question: Rate the patient’s level of consciousness: alert (normal), vigilant (hyperalert), lethargic (drowsy, easily aroused), stupor (difficult to arouse), or coma (unarousable)?

The scale may not identify the full spectrum of patients with delirium, but all patients who are acutely confused should be presumed delirious. A course that fluctuates over hours or days and may worsen at night is known as sundowning. It is typically seen in delirium, but is not essential for the diagnosis.

Other screening tools that can aid in identifying patients with delirium are:

  • Nursing Delirium Screening Scale (NuDESC)
  • Organic Brain Syndrome Scale
  • Delirium Rating Scale
  • ICU version of the CAM
  • Delirium Detection Score

Related Pearl: Delirium vs Dementia

Delirium

Dementia

Hallmark is impaired consciousness

Loss of memory and intellectual abilities

More common in children and elderly 

More common in the elderly 

Associated physical findings:

  • Acute medical illness 
  • Autonomic dysfunction
  • Abnormal EEG 
  • Carphologia or floccillation (picking movements at cover-sheets and clothes) 

Associated physical findings:

  • No medical illness
  • Little autonomic dysfunction
  • Normal EEG 

Psychological findings:

  • Impaired consciousness
  • Illusion, delusion 
  • Sundowning (symptoms much worse at night) 

Psychological findings:

  • Normal consciousness
  • Depressed mood 
  • Personality changes in early stages in Pick’s disease 

Course:

  • Develops quickly
  • Fluctuating course with lucid intervals (waxing and waning) 

Course:

  • Insidious-onset
  • Progressive downhill course

Causes:

  • CNS disease (E.g: Huntington or Parkinson disease)
  • CNS trauma
  • CNS infection (E.g: Meningitis)
  • Systemic disease (E.g., hepatic, cardiovascular)
  • Substance abuse/withdrawal
  • HIV infection
  • Prescription drug overdose (E.g: atropine) 

Causes:

  • Alzheimer's disease
  • Vascular disease (15-30% of all dementias)
  • CNS disease (E.g., Huntingtons or Parkinsons disease)
  • CNS infection (HIV, Prion diseases)
  • Lewy body dementia
  • Pick's disease (Frontotemporal dementia) 

Treatment:

Treat the underlying medical cause

Treatment:

Acetylcholinesterase inhibitors (donepezil, rivastigmine) and NMDA antagonist (memantine)

questions.text: A young woman presented with a rash as shown in the image below. She also complains of recurrent oral ulcers and pain in multiple joints. Investigations revealed antibodies to double-stranded DNA. What is her diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A young woman with a butterfly-shaped malar rash, a history of recurrent oral ulcers, pain in multiple joints, and antibodies to double-stranded DNA is suggestive of systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE).

SLE is an autoimmune disorder that results in damage to multiple organs and organ systems in the body most commonly seen in women of reproductive age.  

Clinical and immunological manifestations of SLE:

  1. Skin
    • acute, subacute cutaneous manifestations (photosensitivity, malar or maculopapular rash)
    • chronic cutaneous manifestations (discoid lupus, panniculitis, lichen planus-like) 
  2. Oral or nasal ulcers
  3. Non-scarring alopecia
  4. Synovitis involving ≥2 joints
  5. Serositis (pleurisy, pericarditis)
  6. Renal: 
    • Protein/Creatinine ratio >0.5
    • RBC casts
  7. Neurologic: seizures, psychosis, myelitis, neuropathy, confusional state
  8. Hemolytic anemia
  9. Leukopenia
  10. Thrombocytopenia
  11. Immunological manifestations
    • Antinuclear antibodies >reference value (positive in >98% patients)
    • Anti-dsDNA >reference value (specific)
    • Anti-Smith antibody (specific)
    • Antiphospholipid antibody (lupus anticoagulant, false-positive rapid plasma reagin)
    • Low serum complement

To diagnose SLE, at least 4 out of 11 of the above criteria must be positive. However, if a renal biopsy is suggestive of lupus nephritis and lupus autoantibodies are positive then four criteria are not required. 

Other options: 

Option A: Dermatomyositis is an inflammatory myopathy that presents with symmetrical weakness in the proximal muscles. Classical dermatological manifestations include- gottron's papules (raised erythematous rash) on the knuckles, and elbows, a shawl sign on the back, and the heliotrope rash over the eyelids (erythematous discoloration with periorbital edema). Laboratory findings include elevated creatinine kinase levels and autoantibodies like anti-Mi2.

Option B: Behcet's disease is a multisystem disorder that requires recurrent oral ulceration plus two of the following criteria for a definitive diagnosis -

  • Recurrent genital ulceration
  • Ocular lesions
  • Skin lesions 
  • Positive pathergy test

Laboratory findings are usually non-specific signs of inflammation and elevated C-reactive protein levels.

Option C: Rheumatoid arthritis is a chronic inflammatory disease that results in damage to the articular cartilage. It can also have a broad range of extra-articular manifestations. The autoantibodies seen in this disease are anti-cyclic citrullinated peptide (anti-CCP) antibodies and rheumatoid factor.

questions.text: A patient presented with pleuritic chest pain and absent breath sounds on the right side. A pleural effusion is suspected. What is the best chest x-ray view to diagnose this condition?
questions.solution:
Lateral decubitus view is the best view to identify pleural effusion. It can identify as little as 25 ml of pleural fluid.

Features of chest radiograph in pleural effusion:

  • Presence of free pleural fluid 
  • Blunting of costophrenic angle 
  • Ellis-S curve – This is a radiological illusion and occurs as a medial radiological density due to the presence of partially aerated lung between the anterior and posterior fluid layers, whereas laterally the density is higher due to the presence of fluid only. The actual fluid level is horizontal.

The image given below shows a lateral decubitus view showing pleural effusion.

Marking A shows fluid layering in the right pleural cavity. Marking B shows the normal width of the lung in the cavity. The amount of pleural fluid can be approximately quantified by measuring the distance A.

Best investigation for minimal pleural effusion is USG.

The minimal amount of fluid required to be detected on imaging for pleural effusion:

  • Lateral view – 75 ml pleural fluid
  • PA view – 200 ml pleural fluid
  • Lateral decubitus - <25 ml pleural fluid

questions.text: A 50-year-old female presented with headache for the past 4 months, she was treated with radiotherapy for vestibular schwannoma 2 year back. What is the probable diagnosis we can arrive from the contrast MRI shown below?
questions.solution:
The most probable diagnosis of the above patient is meningioma.

The well-defined, hyper intense and homogeneously enhanced mass close to the midline, situated extra-axially (i.e., outside the brain parenchyma). Being non-glial in origin they arise from the meningocytes or arachnoid cap cells of the meninges, and thus can occur anywhere meninges are found.

Meningomas are associated with:

  • Female predominance (some meningiomas contain estrogen and progesterone receptors).
  • Genetic preponderance: Genetic mutations associated with meningioma are NF-2 and MEN1 mutations.
  • Ionizing radiation

Useful descriptive signs on MRI are:

  • CSF vascular cleft sign helps to establish that mass to be extra-axial. There is a cleft between tumor and normal brain parenchyma.
  • Dural tail sign: Refers to the linear extension of enhancement the dura, beyond the segment on which the tumor is based.
  • Sunburst or spoke wheel appearance of the vessels.

questions.text: During your ICU rotations, you see a  patient being ventilated with the following apparatus. What does the part marked as A represent?
questions.solution:
The above image shows a self-inflating bag and mask and the part marked as A represents the oxygen inlet.

Bag and mask ventilation is used as a first step in airway management. It serves as a rescue technique to provide oxygenation and ventilation in patients with difficult airways until tracheal intubation is achieved. 

Mask ventilation is not preferred in patients with an increased risk of regurgitation. It should be used with caution in patients with severe facial trauma.
